title: Question 9
prompt: Choose the answer that is written correctly and shows the correct capitalization and punctuation. Be sure the answer you choose is complete.
feedback:
This sentence is correct: “Jon, a welder, works hard every day.” The phrase “a welder” gives more information about Jon. This type of explanatory phrase is called an “appositive.” It tells you something about Jon but isn’t necessary to the rest of the sentence. An appositive is set off by commas before and after it.

This sentence is incorrect: “The welding company, Welders Inc. employs 50 people.” The company name “Welders Inc.” is also an appositive, so it should have a comma after it as well as one before it.

In the sentence “Marco Jon's boss, helps him learn,” the appositive is “Jon’s boss.” It explains more about Marco. It should have a comma before it as well as one after it.

This sentence is also incorrect: “A demanding job welding, requires special skills.” In this sentence “a demanding job” explains more about welding. It should be set off by a comma after it, since it comes at the beginning of the sentence. The subject of the sentence is “welding,” and the subject should not be separated from the verb by a comma. This sentence should read: “A demanding job, welding requires special skills.”
